item__Dynamic.Subtitle: Upstream projects offer many possibilities through plugins and free services
item__Dynamic.Text:
Silex is built using three significant open source projects: GrapesJS, 11ty, Gitlab.

When choosing Silex it is important to know what it is built with, because we owe these projects a lot of love, and also because developers can integrate GrapesJS plugins to add new design capabilities, use 11ty plugins to enhance site generation features, liverage Gitlab pages and Gitlab pipelines for custom deployments, thus tailoring Silex to meet specific needs and expanding its functionality significantly.

item__Dynamic.Title: GrapesJs
item__Dynamic.Text: GrapesJS is an open-source web builder framework that provides the backbone for the Silex interface. It allows users to design web pages visually, using a drag-and-drop interface that is intuitive and accessible even to those without extensive programming knowledge. GrapesJS is versatile and customizable, making it an excellent choice for creating a flexible design platform like Silex, where users can craft responsive web pages using pre-designed blocks and custom styles. Please consider supporting GrapesJs.

item__Dynamic.Title: 11ty
item__Dynamic.Text:
11ty (Eleventy) is a simpler, more user-friendly static site generator. It converts templates and content into static HTML, ensuring the websites are fast, secure, and easy to host. In the context of Silex, 11ty handles the generation of the final static site from the designs created in the GrapesJS-based interface. This means users can design with Silex and have their projects built into static sites that are optimized for performance and SEO, without needing the complexities typically associated with dynamic site generators. Please consider supporting 11ty.

Together, these tools empower Silex to offer a no-code solution that balances ease of use with powerful, professional results, making web development accessible to a broader audience while supporting more experienced developers with robust tools for customization and optimization.

item__Dynamic.Title: GitLab
item__Dynamic.Text: GitLab plays a crucial role in the Silex ecosystem, providing tools for hosting, version control, collaboration, and deployment via GitLab Pages. It offers a comprehensive environment where users can manage backups, automate builds, and deploy websites effortlessly. Gitlab also has a SaaS/online version with a generous free plan so that you can host your websites for free, with many options such as custom domains (all free of charge)

item__Dynamic.Title: Silex for web professionnals
item__Dynamic.Text:
Welcome to the future of web development for agencies and professionals! Silex offers a powerful no-code solution that transforms your workflow, providing the flexibility and control you need to create stunning websites with ease. Designed with the needs of web agencies in mind, Silex allows you to break free from the limitations of traditional platforms like WordPress/Elementor, Framer and Webflow.

Use cases

  • Hire a freelancer for support, specific development etc.

  • (co)Fund a feature you need thanks to the sponsorship in the roadmap (enrol here)

  • Host a private instance of Silex: as a web agency you probably want to control / optimize development time and quality of the websites

  • Host a public instance of Silex: hosting companies will want to integrate Silex to their infrastructures and let users connect to their virtual hosts

Key Benefits

  1. Unlock teams and collaboration

  2. On-premise hosting with GitLab, Silex, and your client's CMS

  3. Seamless transition from WordPress, Elementor, Framer or Webflow

  4. Easy sys-admin with CapRover integration

  5. Coming soon: YunoHost, Coolify, Elest.io for self-hosting

Silex has revolutionized our workflow at Internet 2000, enabling us to create eco-friendly, sustainable websites.

The self-hosting option eliminates usage limits and recurring costs, and allows for extensive customizations and powerful integrations like GrapesJS, 11ty, and GitLab. Silex's CMS feature, with its GraphQL API, has made content management seamless for our clients, with Directus, WordPress headless or Strapi depending on the context.

Additionally, we contribute to Silex's development, enhancing the platform for the entire community. This collaboration ensures continuous improvement and innovation.

Additionally, contributing tutorials, documentation, and designs to Silex has been incredibly rewarding, helping to improve the platform for the entire community. I highly recommend Silex to any web designer looking for a powerful and efficient tool to elevate their projects.

item__Dynamic.Title: About Silex funding and associated business model
item__Dynamic.Text:
Silex is a public project hosted on v3.silex.me, licensed as GNU AGPL, owned by its contributors. For that reason Silex  is Free and Open Source software, forever.

Is Silex really free? Why?

  • We are passionate project contributors and designers who use Silex for personal and professional projects. Also Silex Labs uses Silex to teach web design to beginners.

  • We work together as a community to develop our tool our way. Collaboration makes the web, not competition.

  • So yes! Silex is free, there are no hidden costs, we do not need to monetize Silex users or their websites or visitors.

Can I do business with Silex?

  • Yes! That is what most of us do and our businesses justify our time spent contributing.

  • Silex is free/libre, no one will prevent you from using it to sell websites or doing business with it.

Why is Silex so "crude" compared to other web page/site building tools?

  • Silex is developed by its users. We are giving our time and energy for features that benefit us individually or our businesses, so yes, Silex has less "shiny" features but has all the key features that we use for clients and professional websites.

Will you sell my personal information or the information of my site visitors?

  • Never!

  • We don't have your data anyway, it is stored in your account (ftp, GitLab, owncloud...) and served by your hosting company or GitLab pages. The websites created with silex do not send or receive any data from us, it is easy to make sure it does not as you have all the files and you can host them anywhere.

item__Dynamic.Title: What You Need To Pay For
item__Dynamic.Text:
So that is not all free after all? Well you might want to purchase things and use it with Silex for your next professional website

Domain name

  • Purchasing a domain name enhances the credibility and visibility of your website, providing a professional and memorable web address. While you can use GitLab's free subdomains for hosting via GitLab Pages, owning a domain allows for a more branded and authoritative online presence. Additionally, you can still use your custom domain with GitLab Pages, offering flexibility in hosting. Domain names typically cost anywhere from $10 to $50 per year, depending on the registrar and the domain extension. Popular places to buy one include GoDaddy, Namecheap, and Google Domains.

Build minutes

  • GitLab Build Minutes are essentially the time that GitLab allows you to use its resources to update or make changes to your website hosted on their platform. If you’re using Silex to create a simple static website without a CMS or dynamic data, you might not need many Build Minutes. However, if you’re using dynamic data and updates your site very frequently during the development process for exemple, then purchasing additional Build Minutes may be necessary, especially if you update your site frequently or have complex build needs. This ensures your updates are processed quickly without waiting for available free minutes, helping maintain your site's performance and accessibility.

Hosting

  • You might consider paying for traditional hosting (php, mysql, ftp) if your website requires specific features that GitLab Pages does not support. For example, if your site needs server-side scripting like PHP (for processing forms directly on the server) or complex redirection rules, traditional hosting services can provide these capabilities. Silex supports direct publication to such hosting via FTP, as long as there is not dynamic data in your site.

  • Opting for traditional hosting might also be a beneficial choice if you're looking for eco-friendly options. Many traditional hosting providers now offer "green hosting" services, which use renewable energy sources or carbon offsetting to minimize environmental impact. These providers focus on sustainable practices, such as energy-efficient servers and reduced data center cooling requirements. This is particularly appealing if you or your organization are committed to environmental responsibility and wish to ensure that your website's hosting aligns with your eco-friendly values. GitLab Pages and similar platforms may not specifically cater to this niche, making traditional hosting a compelling choice for those prioritizing sustainability in their web presence.

Self-Hosting

  • To host your own instance of Silex, several options are available. You can choose our partner Elestio, which donates a portion of their revenue to support the development of Silex. It is also possible to use a VPS (Virtual Private Server) with or without solutions like CapRover or YunoHost to simplify server management. See the documentation on self-hosting here. Providers like Heroku can also be a viable solution for self-hosting your Silex site, offering flexibility and control over your hosting environment.

  • For an agency, self-hosting a Silex instance has several advantages. Firstly, it allows complete control over the hosting environment, providing flexibility to customize configurations and meet clients' specific needs. By self-hosting, an agency can also ensure better security and data privacy by fully managing access, backups, and hosting on servers other than GitLab’s. Additionally, this approach can reduce long-term costs by avoiding recurring fees related to the intensive use of GitLab, which requires purchasing "build minutes."

  • For hosting providers, offering self-hosting services for Silex can attract new clients looking to leverage the benefits of no-code while enjoying the performance and flexibility of self-hosting solutions. By supporting Silex users, hosting providers can also strengthen their market position by offering a dedicated service to website creators. Of course, a hosting provider can offer their clients a Silex instance integrated into their infrastructure, with backups on their servers and the published site hosted on the client’s purchased vhost.

Silex Community Update | Oct 24

Official Website, Squidex Integration, and More!

Hello everyone!

This month marks a major milestone for Silex! 🎉 The new official website is live, a collaborative effort between Brice (design) and Olivier (proofreading).

Let’s dive into the latest news and see what Silex has to offer!

➡️ Try Silex now on v3.silex.me

🌟 Website of the Month: The New Official Silex Website
We are thrilled to introduce the new official Silex website (now live on www.silex.me)! 🎉

After more than a year of creative collaboration, Brice designed and integrated the entire website, while Olivier meticulously proofread to ensure every detail is perfect.

The site is powered by a modern architecture: Silex for visual creation, Squidex as the CMS, and GitLab Pages for hosting. A 100% free solution, with only the domain name paid for!

Performance-wise, the results are impressive:

This website perfectly reflects Silex’s independent spirit and provides a fast and smooth user experience. We can’t wait to hear your feedback!

🚀 October Development Updates
This month, the Silex team has brought several significant improvements to the project:

  • Squidex Integration: The integration with the Squidex CMS is a major advancement. The new official Silex website now runs on a powerful architecture: Silex + Squidex + GitLab Pages, providing a similar user experience to Webflow + Webflow CMS, but using free and open-source tools. In Silex, you design and manage the look of your site, while Squidex dynamically manages the content. This combination offers a powerful, flexible, and completely free solution.

  • FTP Bug Fix: Thanks to Olivier, FTP compatibility has been greatly improved. You can now publish your site to any hosting provider using FTP. Simply log in to v3.silex.me, select FTP as your publishing method, and enter your server details. The interface is user-friendly, similar to Webflow, but with the freedom to choose your hosting provider.

These updates make Silex more flexible and powerful, allowing for fully customizable content management and hosting. 🎉

➡️ Publish your site easily with v3.silex.me

💡 Tip of the Month: Custom Domains with Silex
A common question in the community is: "Does Silex offer custom domains?" The answer is simple: Silex doesn’t offer custom domains directly, but with GitLab Pages, you can easily set up a custom domain for free, or let GitLab assign you a *.gitlab.io domain.

The user experience is smooth: after publishing your site from Silex, you’re redirected to GitLab, where you can manage your domain settings directly. This gives you full control over your site’s appearance and accessibility.

🔧 Feature Request of the Month: Silex Desktop
One of the popular topics on our roadmap is the development of Silex Desktop, an installable application for Windows, macOS, and Linux. This version of Silex would allow you to work faster with local files and even offline.

A few months ago, Tarek suggested using Tauri instead of Electron for developing the app. Tauri offers many advantages, including better performance, a smaller footprint, and a reduced environmental impact. Switching to Tauri would align with Silex’s open-source and eco-friendly values, while significantly reducing the app's size.

If you’re interested in this project, feel free to join the discussion on the Silex community forum, participate on the Silex chat, or vote on the Silex Desktop roadmap to help move this feature forward!

🔗 Libre Friends: Powered by the Silex Labs Association
We’re happy to announce that the Libre Friends project, powered by the Silex Labs Association, continues to grow and welcome new members. Libre Friends is a directory of open-source software aimed at promoting tools that respect users' freedom. You can learn more by visiting the Libre Friends website.

This month, two new projects joined the initiative:

  1. GrapesJS: The framework that Silex uses for front-end design. It’s a go-to tool for visual design and content editing.

  2. Keila: The newsletter tool we’re using to send this very newsletter! Keila is a free, open-source solution for managing and sending email campaigns.

Of course, Silex is also part of this initiative. You can check out the Silex Libre Friends page on the Silex community website.

If you know any projects that should join Libre Friends, let us know! And feel free to explore the listed tools to discover high-quality open-source solutions!

📢 Community Contributions and Call for Testers
We’ve recently integrated the Squidex CMS into the new official Silex website. This integration is still in the refinement phase, and we’re working on clear documentation to make it easy for everyone to use this setup.

If you have a few minutes to spare, we’re looking for testers for this new configuration and proofreaders for the upcoming documentation. Your contributions will be invaluable in improving the user experience and ensuring the integration is accessible to all.

Feel free to join us on the Silex chat or the community forums to discuss further. Together, we can continue to evolve Silex!

Warm regards,
Alex Hoyau

June has brought us more exciting developments and contributions, driving Silex forward faster than ever. Here's what's new and noteworthy!

🌟 Site of the Month: Clay Group

We're proud to showcase this month's standout project, a beautifully crafted website by Internet 2000, built with Silex and Directus. The site exemplifies top-notch performance and user experience:

Clay Group is an innovative platform dedicated to fostering collaborations and sharing resources within the creative industry.

Check it out to see how Silex and Directus can bring dynamic data to life in a visually stunning and highly performant website.

🚀 Silex Development Update: Current Contributions

We now have three contributors actively enhancing the Silex codebase:

  • Simon: He's improving productivity by adding numerous keyboard shortcuts and other enhancements.

  • Olivier: He's implementing an easy way to publish websites live with GitLab Pages, making Silex's UX comparable to commercial SaaS products like Framer and Webflow. This feature allows seamless website publication with just a button click, leveraging your existing GitLab login. Of course, you can still publish to any hosting via FTP or download the site files as a ZIP archive.

  • Alex (me): I'm working on Silex CMS, which allows designers to create websites in Silex using content from WordPress or Directus, with more CMS integrations to come. This feature simplifies content management, enabling both designers and clients to update content effortlessly. Learn more about Silex CMS here.

  • Someone nice on mastodon contributed this design for Silex login page

For more on upcoming features, visit roadmap.silex.me.

🆕 This Month's Releases

  • UI Improvements: Enhanced the publication dialog and class selection tool.

  • Bug Fixes: Various issues resolved to improve overall stability.

  • Notification Panel: Now, if your website has dead links, deleted images still being referenced, or other errors, you'll receive notifications.

  • Onboarding Enhancements: When you connect to Silex with GitLab, you'll receive an email with links to the documentation, and another one post-publication. These messages are also visible as notifications within Silex.

📢 Marketing Contributions Wanted

  • Website Rewrite: I'm working on the next version of silex.me with 10 pages online. I need help with reading and rewriting.

  • New Pitch Feedback: Here's a draft of our new pitch – "Silex is an online tool for visually creating static sites with dynamic data. With the free/libre spirit of the internet, together." I would love your feedback on this.

  • Onboarding Feedback: Is our new onboarding process effective? I need help refining and improving it.

📝 Give 5 Minutes of Your Time

We value your feedback! Share your experiences with Silex by leaving a review on Trustpilot. Your insights help others discover the power of free and open web design with Silex.

If you haven't used Silex yet, why not take 5 minutes to try it out on our free server provided by the Silex Labs non-profit organization? Then leave a review!

Feel free to reply to this email if you have any questions or suggestions. I'm here to help!

Yours freely,
Alex Hoyau
